channel.title: NYT > World News

item.title: ‘It’s Collective Punishment’: Iran Exacts Heavy Price on Protest Supporters
item.description: The authorities are making mass arrests, seizing assets and hunting down doctors who treated protesters. Some Iranians keep showing defiance anyway.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Leily Nikounazar and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:description: Members of an Iranian counterterrorism police unit at a pro-government rally in Tehran last month.

item.title: Starmer Apologizes for Ex-Ambassador Mandelson’s Epstein Ties
item.description: Newly released documents detailed connections between the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and Peter Mandelson, who was picked to be the U.S. envoy by the British prime minister, Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain has vowed to hold Peter Mandelson accountable and has apologized to Jeffrey Epstein’s victims.

item.title: Thousands Displaced by Military Operation in Pakistan
item.description: Some 60,000 evacuees have been left in limbo by confusion and political disputes as Pakistan battles insurgents on its border with Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman

item.title: Residents of Cortina, a Winter Olympics Hub, Are Angry About All the Construction
item.description: In Cortina d’Ampezzo, a hub for the Games in northern Italy, some residents, including a former Olympian, are annoyed about all the construction. Others are annoyed that they’re annoyed.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laborers in Cortina d’Ampezzo working in January to finish a ski lift before the Winter Games begin.

item.title: Carney Increases E.V. Investments as Trump’s Trade Policy Disrupts Canada’s Auto Industry
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced several measures Thursday aimed at making Canada a global leader in electric vehicles and rescuing an industry ravaged by U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Eduardo Lima/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada, right, visiting an auto parts plant on Thursday in Woodbridge, Ontario.

item.title: Ukraine-Russia Talks End With Little Progress and Hints of Impasse
item.description: American negotiators trumpeted plans for a prisoner swap, but that was small recompense for months of diplomatic efforts by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:description: Working on Wednesday at a power plant in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was heavily damaged by recent Russian missile and drone strikes.

item.title: Mayor of Tequila, Mexico, Is Accused of Shaking Down Tequila Companies
item.description: The mayor of the city that is the birthplace of the bottled spirit is the latest official to be arrested as Mexico targets cartel-related corruption.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Lindsay Lauckner Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blue agave, grown for tequila, in Jalisco state, Mexico.

item.title: Deaths in Boat Disaster in English Channel Were Avoidable, Inquiry Finds
item.description: The report blamed people smugglers and “systemic failure” on the part of the authorities after about 30 people drowned as they tried to reach Britain from France in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Belongings left by migrants near Wimereux, France, before they tried to cross the English Channel to reach Britain in November 2021.

item.title: ‘My Crazy Friend’: The Royals Who Stayed Close to Epstein
item.description: Emails, texts, photos and videos show how Jeffrey Epstein, even after becoming a convicted sex offender, burnished his ties to royal family members from several countries and their advisers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Lise Aserud/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway at an event in Oslo in 2024.

item.title: Iranian Nobel Peace Laureate Starts New Hunger Strike in Prison
item.description: The rights activist Narges Mohammadi is protesting her continued detention, her family said. She was arrested again in December after being given leave from prison for medical treatment.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Nooshin Jafari/Middle East Images, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Narges Mohammadi in Tehran last year while on temporary leave from prison. She was released for medical treatment in 2024 before being arrested again last year.

item.title: Italy Toughens Protest Laws, Hours Before Planned Rallies at Winter Olympics
item.description: The restrictions could affect people demonstrating this weekend outside Olympic events in northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Outside San Siro Stadium in Milan, a venue for the 2026 Winter Olympic Games, on Wednesday.

item.title: At Ukraine’s Request, Starlink Denies Internet Access to Russian Troops
item.description: It’s unclear what effect the change will have on Russia’s ability to wage war, but Russian military bloggers said troops were experiencing internet outages that hampered frontline communications.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier preparing a Starlink satellite internet system in the Donetsk region in 2024. Russians have been evading export restrictions to smuggle in Starlink devices and send them to the front.

item.title: The Louvre Thieves Dropped This Priceless Crown. Now It Looks Like This.
item.description: Empress Eugénie’s crown was left lying on the sidewalk after the Louvre Museum heist in October. The museum has now released pictures of the damage.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter

item.title: LA Olympics Chief Keeps Low Profile in Milan Games After Appearing in Epstein Files
item.description: Casey Wasserman, who is leading preparations for the 2028 Summer Games, has expressed “regret” after messages he exchanged with Ghislaine Maxwell decades ago surfaced.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Shawn Hubler
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)
item.media:description: Casey Wasserman, chairman of the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles, addressing members of the International Olympic Committee in Milan on Tuesday.

item.title: She’s Upending Japanese Politics With Two Words: ‘I’m Pregnant’
item.description: Hikaru Fujita, who’s running in Sunday’s parliamentary election, is a standout in a country where expectant mothers rarely enter national politics.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hikaru Fujita, a candidate for Parliament, in Azumino City, Nagano Prefecture, on Tuesday.

item.title: The Olympics Are a Show Of Global Harmony. The World is Anything But.
item.description: The Winter Games, which officially open in Italy on Friday, are rooted in international cooperation. That feels out of place to some in a world where old rules no longer apply.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The Olympic rings in Livigno, Italy.

item.title: Milan Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony: How to Watch, Timing and More
item.description: They will take place at 2 p.m. Eastern on Friday across four separate venues in Northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:description: A training session at Livigno Snow Park in Italy on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Set for Talks in Oman
item.description: Middle Eastern diplomats see a chance for negotiations on Iran’s nuclear program but have slim hopes for progress on other U.S. demands.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard at a square in Tehran last month portrayed a strike on a U.S. carrier.

item.title: Argentina and U.S. Sign Sweeping Trade Deal as Alliance Deepens
item.description: The deal reduces reciprocal tariffs and expands quotas for key trading goods, including Argentine beef — a flashpoint for American ranchers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: President Trump with President Javier Milei of Argentina at the White House in October.

item.title: Toronto Police Charged in Sweeping Drug and Corruption Case
item.description: After hit men targeted the home of a prison manager in June, investigators say, the schemes of a criminal network involving the police unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Jon Blacker/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, Chief Myron Demkiw of the Toronto police, Chief Jim MacSween and Deputy Chief Ryan Hogan of the York Regional Police at a news conference on Thursday in Aurora, Ontario.

item.title: It’s Time for the Olympics
item.description: The Games are supposed to bring people from around the globe together, but there’s no escaping politics.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: At a Bonobo’s ‘Tea Party,’ Scientists Find Hints of Imagination
item.description: In a playtime experiment, researchers found that our closest living relatives have the capacity for make-believe, too.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: How We Know Iran Crushed Protests with Lethal Force
item.description: The New York Times collected and analyzed hundreds of videos of a crackdown on anti-government protests that Iranians shared despite an internet blackout. Sanjana Varghese explains how the Visual Investigations team at The Times verified them.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese, Christina Thornell, James Surdam, Jon Hazell and Zach Caldwell

item.title: Jessie Diggins is the Olympian Testing the Limits of Endurance
item.description: Jessie Diggins has become the best-ever American cross-country skier because of what she pushes her body through.
item.dc:creator: Reid Forgrave
item.media:credit: Holly Andres for The New York Times

item.title: Nuclear Arms Control Era Comes to End Amid Global Rush for New Weapons
item.description: Beijing, Moscow and shaken American allies are seeking new warheads as President Trump ends more than a half century of nuclear arms control with Russia.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Alaska last year.

item.title: Rethinking Shakespeare in Shanghai
item.description: A recent production of “Othello” proves that small creative flowers can grow between the dreary slabs of cultural concrete laid by the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times

item.title: Venezuela Said to Detain Maduro Allies Targeted by the U.S.
item.description: The questioning of the politically connected businessmen, Raúl Gorrín and Alex Saab, signaled deepening cooperation between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Annie Correal

item.title: U.S. and Iran to Hold Talks in Oman on Friday
item.description: The White House confirmed a meeting would take place after days of conflicting reports on the talks’ timing, location and format.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, was expected to meet with U.S. envoys in Oman on Friday.

item.title: Canada’s Tate McRae Roots for Team USA in New Olympics Ad
item.description: Tate McRae’s promotional video for NBC, in which she name checks Team USA athletes, has drawn the ire of some Canadians as the country’s relationship with the United States hits new lows.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Tate McRae in December in Los Angeles.

item.title: Dutch Queen Joins the Military
item.description: Queen Máxima of the Netherlands enlisted as a reservist, the Royal House said, because the country’s security “can no longer be taken for granted.”
item.dc:creator: Koba Ryckewaert
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Royal House showing Queen Máxima of the Netherlands during military training in Breda on Wednesday.

item.title: Babies, Robots and Climate Change
item.description: It’s often assumed that lower birthrates could help slow climate change and A.I. disruption. The reality is more complex.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times

item.title: Russian Comedian Accused of Making a Joke About Veterans Gets Prison Time
item.description: The comedian, Artemy Ostanin, was convicted of “inciting hatred” by making a joke during a stand-up routine in March.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: The Russian comedian Artemy Ostanin, standing during a court appearance last year in Moscow, said his joke did not mention soldiers.

item.title: Two Quit Human Rights Watch Over Shelved Report Criticizing Israel
item.description: Omar Shakir and Milena Ansari said they had quit over the stalled publication of a report that concludes it is a crime against humanity to deny Palestinians the ability to return to the territory that is now Israel.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Jerusalem in 2021.

item.title: Nigeria Attack Leaves More Than 160 Dead
item.description: The raiders stormed a rural community in central Nigeria, killing dozens and setting homes on fire in one of the country’s worst recent attacks.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Ismail Auwal and Saikou Jammeh

item.title: Chevron Agrees to Explore Oil and Gas Work in Syria
item.description: Chevron has signed an initial agreement to start working in Syria, weeks after the Syrian government seized control of key oil and gas fields in the north of the country.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Tishrin oil field in northeastern Syria on Wednesday.

item.title: France’s Raid on X Escalates Trans-Atlantic Showdown Over Social Media
item.description: The French investigation into Elon Musk’s X illustrated a fundamental divide between European and American leaders about how to regulate social media — or whether to restrict it at all.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: A poster in London featuring an image of Elon Musk, calling for X users to delete their accounts.

item.title: John Steenhuisen, South African Party Leader, to Step Down
item.description: John Steenhuisen, who led a party supporting the A.N.C. in a coalition government, is leaving after controversies about his handling of a livestock virus and Uber Eats orders.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: John Steenhuisen votes for the speaker of the National Assembly in Cape Town, South Africa, in 2024.

item.title: Israel Launches Deadly Strikes on Gaza, Saying Militants Attacked Its Soldiers
item.description: Gaza officials said the Israeli airstrikes killed at least 21 Palestinians. Israel said one of its soldiers was critically wounded in the attack by Palestinian gunmen.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Natan Odenheimer

item.title: Former Prince Andrew Moves Out of Royal Home Amid Fresh Epstein Revelations
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was stripped of his titles last year and told to give up his grand residence because of growing concern over his links to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor riding a horse in Windsor Great Park, near to Royal Lodge, on Monday.

item.title: Yair Golan’s Battle for a Two-State Solution and the Future of Israel
item.description: To many Israelis, he’s a war hero. To others, he’s a traitor guilty of “blood libel.” Can Yair Golan change politics in Israel?
item.dc:creator: Ruth Margalit
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Golan at an open discussion in December at Kibbutz Naan.

item.title: Two Chinese Journalists Are Detained for Reporting on Corruption
item.description: The move against the men, who wrote an article that was critical of a local official, demonstrates how the space for independent voices has shrunk in China.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Hu in 2019. He and another Chinese journalist were recently detained after writing about a local official in Sichuan Province.

item.title: At Least 15 Die in Rare Collision Between Migrant Boat and Greek Patrol Vessel
item.description: Deadly shipwrecks often occur in the Aegean Sea, which is one of the main maritime routes to Europe, but they generally involve migrant boats sinking in stormy weather.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Emergency workers on the eastern Aegean island of Chios, Greece, on Wednesday. The exact circumstances of the collision were not immediately clear.

item.title: For Peace, More Ukrainians Consider the Once Unthinkable: Surrendering Land
item.description: Polls show a growing acceptance of territorial concessions among a war-weary public, if Ukraine receives strong security guarantees.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: The fate of the Donbas region is among the thorniest of issues in peace talks.

item.title: Bulgarians Adopt the Euro With a Whisper of Melancholy but Few Tears
item.description: In a country roiled by political upheaval recently, retiring the longtime currency, the lev, prompted some concern about inflation but little other angst.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Boryana Dzhambazova
item.media:description: A billboard in Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, on New Year’s Day. The changeover to euros was long anticipated but divided public opinion nonetheless.

item.title: Here’s How the U.S. Accepted Danish Control of Greenland 100 Years Ago.
item.description: In 1917, the United States bought Caribbean islands from Denmark and agreed to respect Denmark’s hold over Greenland. The deal resurfaced with President Trump’s recent threats to seize Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue commemorating Hans Egede, a Danish missionary who founded Nuuk, the capital of Greenland, in the 18th century, overlooking the city last year.

item.title: In Afghanistan, a Trail of Hunger and Death Behind U.S. Aid Cuts
item.description: Afghanistan has plunged deeper into a crisis marked by levels of child hunger unseen in 25 years and the closure of almost 450 health centers.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Yaqoob Akbary, Safiullah Padshah and Tomás Munita
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times

item.title: A Journalist Who Looks for Clues in Plain Sight
item.description: On The Times’s Visual Investigations team, Christiaan Triebert combines social media sleuthing and traditional reporting to piece together complex stories.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Gloves Come Off in Gulf as Trump’s Closest Arab Allies Clash
item.description: A feud between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates is reshaping conflicts and alliances across the Middle East and Africa.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: The site of a recent car-bomb attack in southern Yemen.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Resume Talks After a Huge Attack by Moscow
item.description: U.S., Russian and Ukrainian negotiators are meeting in the United Arab Emirates, but Russia continues to pummel Ukraine and has not softened demands that Kyiv calls unacceptable.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency workers spray water on a damaged residential building following an air attack in Kharkiv on Tuesday.

item.title: How 2026 Winter Olympics Security Is Preparing For The Opening Ceremony
item.description: Thousands of Italian security officers will be deployed, though the presence of U.S. ICE personnel has stirred anger. Italian officials said Wednesday they had thwarted a Russian cyberattack aimed at some Olympics hotels.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Italian carabinieri in Milan on Sunday. The city is hosting the Winter Olympics this month.

item.title: South Korea Questions Cram School Culture and Childhood Stress
item.description: Academic pressure has become so intense that even preschoolers are taking private extracurricular classes, raising worries about children’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Jean Chung
item.media:description: Seoul has “Therapy Zone” boxes, soundproof spaces where students can study, or vent, in the evenings after school.

item.title: ‘Neoroyalism’ and What It Says About Trump
item.description: Experts are reaching to divine the president’s approach to global policy and economics, with one theory seeing antecedents in centuries-old dynastic rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman gave President Trump a warm and opulent welcome in Saudi Arabia last year.

item.title: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, Son of Libyan Dictator, Is Killed
item.description: Mr. el-Qaddafi, 53, a politician and a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was killed after four men stormed his house, the lawyer said. No other details were released.
item.dc:creator: Islam Al-Atrash and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi gave an interview to The New York Times in Tripoli, Libya, in 2011.

item.title: All About the Epstein Files
item.description: Everyone seems to have questions about the sprawling scandal, so we talked to a reporter who’s been following the case for years.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: U.K. Investigates Peter Mandelson Over Jeffrey Epstein Ties
item.description: Peter Mandelson, a prominent British political figure, faces allegations of “misconduct in public office offenses” over his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Peter Mandelson last year.

item.title: Paris Court Deals Family Blow in Battle for Rent From the French Embassy in Iraq
item.description: The court said it was not the right authority to handle the lawsuit for unpaid rent, and the case should be heard in Iraq, where the family’s ancestors had fled persecution.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Provided by the Lawee and Khazzam families
item.media:description: The French Embassy in Baghdad is in a house built in the 1930s.

item.title: U.S. Fighter Jet Shoots Down Iranian Drone Amid Heightened Tensions
item.description: A U.S. fighter jet shot down the Iranian drone after it “unnecessarily maneuvered” toward the Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: F/A-18 fighter jets parked on the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln in 2024.
